project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
eWhen planning a sprint via a scrum board in planning mode, the time estimates on sub-tasks are not reflected in their parent issues, OR in the "workload by assignee" panel. This causes a lot of unnecessary additional overhead.

When planning a sprint, we like to sketch out about a dozen top-level stories. We then create sub-tasks under those stories, which inherit things like the epic & sprint from their parent. Typically, we only assign estimates to sub-tasks. 

This allows us to create stories that involve multiple participants, and it allows us to have a quick, high-level understanding of what's contained in a sprint and how everything relates to each other... after all, when there are (conceptually) less than a dozen things going on, it's easy to wrap your head around them.

That is the critical constraint: a story may have sub-tasks assigned to different people. For example, we might have a story with sub-tasks like so:

* Revise internal API Foo (Story)
** Plan API change (Bob, 8h)
** API review & refinement meeting (Bob, 4h)
** API review & refinement meeting (Sheila, 4h)
** API review & refinement meeting (Sam, 4h)
** Update API implementation Bar (Sheila, 16h)
** Update client libraries (Sam, 12h)

There is absolutely no way that a top-level estimate on that story is meaningful on its own. It can be useful as a measure of person-hours, but only if that estimate is directly derived from the issue's sub-tasks, and only if the estimates are correctly reflected in each assignee's workload.

We've tried totaling up the hours in the sub-tasks and just hacking them into the top-level issues during planning, but that's terrible: it's a total hassle, and it doesn't work for multiple assignees without reorganizing our issues in totally distorted ways to accommodate the tool rather than our team.

The best solution we've found so far is to put together a dashboard with Workload Pie gadgets. That's sort of okay, but it requires us to continually switch away from the scrum board during our planning meetings, so it's still sub-optimal.

I don't know if this behavior is a design decision or simply a bug, but it's causing us a lot of headache. Please fix it. Thanks!
fields.summary: Issue estimates not correct in scrum board planning mode (not reflecting sub-tasks)

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
As a user of JIRA I would like the burn down chart to also plot a line representing the number of sub-tasks which are not yet done. For many sprints that have sub-tasks, the number of story points only starts to go down near the end of the sprint, e.g. due to testing that can only commence after development has been done first.

To match the scale of the story points, each sub-task would be reported as the number of story points for that user story divided by the number of sub-tasks for that user story. Stories without any sub-tasks would be reported as a single sub-task with the same amount of story points. Implementing this would give more insight of when progress is being made in a sprint.
fields.summary: Show sub-tasks in burn down

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

When using Epics as a Swimlane, if the Epics are from a different project (one that is not covered in the filter of the board), any tasks under that Epic will not show up in the board, even if the task rightfully belong to that board. For example :

* Given Project A and Project B
* Project A has a Rapid board with a filter that only shows issues in Project A
* Project B has an Epic, called Epic B
* Task A from Project A is linked to Epic B via Epic Link
* In the Rapid board, the swimlanes are configured to be based on Epics
* Even though Task A shows up in the board (in the backlog), it does not show in the Sprint due to the Swimlane settings (and due Epic B being from another project)

h3. Suggested Solution

Although it has been explained in [GHS-7286|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/GHS-7286] that it is an expected behavior that the Epic tag is missing in the backlog, it gets more complex in this case as the Task itself is not showing up in the board at all. This should be handled better, perhaps by adding a section called 'External Epics' when viewing the Sprint.

Alternatively, this can be avoided if the 'Epic Link' field is limited to only show Epics from the selected project, as per - [GHS-12016|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/GHS-12016]
 
h3. Workaround 
For now, the only workaround would be to not configure Epics as the Swimlane
fields.summary: As a user I want tasks linked to external Epics to show up in the Epic Swimlane so I can work on them

*What*
When changing issue type to epic, the "Epic name" is not prompt to be filled out and there fore the issue does not function as an epic.

*Steps to reproduce*

1. Create Issue with the issue type *Bug*
2. Click Edit button, change Issue type to *Epic* 
or
2. In-line edit issue type, by directly changing the issue type to *Epic* on the issue view screen
3. There is no prompt to fill in the Epic Name
4. Click on edit and you can see the Epic Name field finally visible but without value.
!epic2.png|thumbnail!

*Workaround 1*
{panel}
1. Use More -> Move -> Chang issue type to Epic -> Next 
!epic3.png|thumbnail!
2. This will prompt additional Epic fields to be filled in especially *Epic Name* which will make the issue function as an epic.
!epic5.png|thumbnail!
{panel}

*Workaround 2*
{panel}
Edit the issue and fill in a value in the required field ( Epic Name )
{panel}
fields.summary: Changing Issue Type to Epic using In-line Edit or Edit Button Should Prompt Epic Name

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce in fresh install:
# Create a board + project.
# Create a Sprint.
# Create an Epic. Open the Epic in detail view, and then edit the Sprint field to include Sprint created in step 2.
# Delete the board's filter. Notice how the board doesn't show up anymore in JIRA.
# Create a new board, but use the existing project created in Step 1.
# In new board, create a new issue.
# Create another sprint, and add issue to this sprint.
# Complete this sprint without completing the issue.
# Go back to backlog, notice how the sprint we created in Step 2 suddenly shows up! (*Even though this new board doesn't show it at first*)

The above scenario is one example of how JIRA Agile is taking into account Future Sprints that are configured in the Sprint field of Epic issue types. 

This causes unexpected behaviour because that "incomplete" Future Sprint is not deleted together with the board when the board's filter is deleted. That Future Sprint then appears unexpectedly on the new board when a sprint on that board is closed. 
Another way for this to happen is when a user manually includes a Future Sprint into the Epic. 

*Workaround*
# Do not configure any Sprints for epics, since epics usually span several sprints anyway.
fields.summary: Future Sprints that are configured in Epics are added to the board when other sprints in the board is completed

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When starting a sprint, it may be necessary to remove a story from the sprint. When doing so, this should remove any points that were associated with that story from the project.

h3. Environment
Server
Cloud 


h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a new Story
# Assign Story points to the new Story
# Create a new Sprint
# Add the Story to the Sprint
# Start the Sprint
# Remove the Story from the Sprint
# End the Sprint
# Run the Epic Burndown Chart Report


h3. Expected Results
The Epic Burndown Chart should be displayed without including the Story Points associated with the Story that was removed from the Sprint


h3. Actual Results
The Epic Burndown Chart will be displayed with the Story Points associated with the Story that was removed from the Sprint


h3.Workaround
There is no current work around for this behavior
fields.summary: Deleting a story in a sprint should remove those estimates entirely

fields.description:
h3. Summary
When viewing the *Velocity Report*, issues punted to another sprint before the end of the sprint and resolved are counted as "Completed", while it is not counted as "Completed" in the *Sprint Report*

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a new project with a Scrum board
# Create two sprints
# Create issues one through 3 and give them Story Points
# Add the three issues to *Sprint 1*
# Complete issues #1 and #2
# Edit issue #3 and change the sprint to *Sprint 2*
# Complete issue #3.
# Complete the Sprint

h3. Expected Results
* The *Sprint Report* would show issues #1 and #2 as "Completed" and #3 as removed from sprint.
* The *Velocity Report* would show the sum of issues #1 and #2 as "Completed" (and sum of the three issues as Commited)

h3. Actual Results
* The *Sprint Report* shows issues #1 and #2 as "Completed" and #3 as removed from sprint. (/)
* The *Velocity Report* shows the sum of issues #1, #2 and #3 as "Completed" (x)

h3. Original Description
{panel}
Completed issues that are removed from the an active sprint before it ends are not included in the total final story points. However, in a velocity report, completed issues that are removed from a sprint are being included. 
{panel}
fields.summary: Completed Issues Removed From Sprint Before It Ends Are Included In Velocity Report

fields.description:
Hi,

We are using JIRA 6.4. For some of our customers, we are using parallel sprints which we name for example "JMP - Sprint 22A" and "JMP - Sprint 22B". I could have issues assigned to me in either sprint, both of which run in parallel at the same time.

I built a filter for "Issues assigned to me" which I use in one of the gadgets on my dashboard. It looks like this:

assignee = currentUser() AND issuetype != Epic AND sprint in openSprints() AND resolution = Unresolved ORDER BY updatedDate DESC

However, for each of my projects, it only returns issues that are in the first parallel sprint, but not in the second. Instead of  "AND sprint in openSprints()" I tried using "AND sprint ~ JMP" as well as "AND sprint = JMP*", but neither one works.

Is the first mentioned problem a known bug?

Thanks,
Martin
fields.summary: JQL in openSprints() doesn't find issues in 2nd parallel sprint

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
It is possible to close a parent issue (set to done) with open sub-tasks. When a user attempts to close a Sprint with these issues, a generic error occurs:

!sprint_closure2.jpg|thumbnail!

{quote}Sprint cannot be completed as there are incomplete subtasks on the following issues:{quote}

h3. Suggested Solution
If there is a closed parent issue with open sub-tasks, it should give the user the option to either move all sub-tasks to *done*, or re-open the parent issue.
 
h3. Workaround 
Re-open the parent issue *or* close the sub-tasks using Bulk Change operations
fields.summary: Unable to close Sprint with closed parent issue and open sub-tasks

*Summary*
When configuring swimlanes inside of JIRA Agile, JQL can be used to display issues. These JQL entries allow for inline editing. When editing the JQL for a swimlane while using Chrome or FireFox, the previously entered JQL remains visible. When doing the same in IE11, the JQL disappears. The JQL should remain as to provide a visual reference to the query they previously had entered.


*Steps to reproduce*
# Select an Agile Project
# Click the 'Board' button in the upper right hand corner of the board
# Select 'Configure' from the dropdown menu
# Click 'Swimlanes' in the left hand menu
# Click on any of the JQL present for any of the swimlanes present


*Workaround*
When editing the JQL for a swimlane, use either Chrome or FireFox.

  {panel}

On my Scrum or Kanban board I'm using the functionality to generate swim lanes using Epics.

It works for locally created epics but not for the one linked from an external project.
Swim lanes and tasks using external epic links  are not being displayed on the board at all... look at screenshot 1.

*Current behavior*

*Requested behavior*

fields.description:
We have subtasks that need to be executed in a very particular order. The subtasks have been ordered correctly when looking at the parent issue, by using the up and down arrows. This does not seem to actually update their ranking though. 

When looking at the rapidboard view, the subtasks are not in the priority order they were put in under the parent issue. The board is ranking by rank. If I go back to the parent issue and use the gear to "rank to top" or "rank to bottom" then the order is updated on the rapidboard but not in the order on the parent issue.

The two are disconnected from one another. You would have to manually rank them twice, using each ranking UI individually. Meaning that you would first go in and rank them all in the Parent Issue view. And then rank all of the sub tasks again on the board. 

I would expect the behavior to function basically the way updating ranking works when filtering by Epic on a backlog. You can update the relative order in just that epic. Then when you clear the filter the order of other issues has not changed. Meaning that if I update the ranking of subtasks on a parent issue, that is changing their relative order. So when looking at the Agile board, other issues may be sprinkled between them but the relative changes are reflected.
fields.summary: Subtask ranking between board view and list in Parent issue disconnected

fields.description:
*Steps to reproduce*
# Create a Sprint "A"
# Drag issues into the new Sprint "A"
# Create another Sprint "B"
# Delete the first Sprint "A", such that the issues fall back into Sprint "B"
# Drag issues into sprint "B"
# Try to start Sprint B. Sprint "B" is started ONLY with the issues dragged in with step 5. The issues which were displayed as being fallen back into Sprint "B" are not part of the sprint anymore.

Refer to attachments for more details.

*Workaround*
This only happens when issue is automatically added to a new sprint when the first sprint is deleted. The workaround would be to explicitly drag the issue to the desired sprint
* Manually drag all issues from Sprint 1 to Sprint 2 *before* deleting Sprint 1
** Sprint 1 should be empty when it is being deleted

fields.description:
According to multiple sources on Scrum development, there are many accepted ways to define story points.

From [Scrum Methodology|http://scrummethodology.com/scrum-effort-estimation-and-story-points]
{quote}
Common estimating methods include t-shirt sizes (S, M, L, and too big), powers of 2 (1, 2, 4, 8), the Fibonacci sequence (1, 2, 3, 5, 8, etc.), or simply small vs. needs-to-be-split
{quote}

That leads to two suggestions:

*#1*
Additional methods of defining story points should be implemented in Agile, allowing Project Administrators to choose the best way to apply story points on their issues.

*#2*
There's no Scrum documentation referring to story points as decimal values, therefore JIRA accepts the input of such values.
fields.summary: Allow choice between types of Story Points

fields.description:
When dragging issues in backlog view, if I'm not moving the mouse then the drag will stop once I drag the issue above the top of the backlog's inner <div>.  

To repro: 
* go to any backlog with a few hundred issues in it. 
* drag an item from the bottom and try to move it far upward. To coninue dragging above the top of the items currently displayed, you must move the mouse upwards until it is above the top of the backlog <div> top of the backlog (e.g. over the search area) 
* stop moving the mouse

Expected: drag continues as long as the mouse position is above the drag area
Actual: drag stops until I wiggle the mouse, then drag continues. I assume JIRA is using a mousemove event to trigger dragging, but if there's no mousemove even then dragging stops. 

This bug means that the only way to drag an issue a long distance through a long backlog is to keep wiggling the mouse back and forth above or below the backlog <div> while you wait, and wait, and wait for 10+ seconds until the dragged issue gets to where you want it to be.  

This makes it incredibly frustrating and time-wasting to groom a large backlog. Ever tried wiggling your mouse for 10 seconds at a time and then doing it again and again for 200 tasks while doing a big backlog-prioritization exercise? It gets really tiring. 

When dragging, consider relying on a timer (not mousemove events) to continue dragging when the cursor has moved outside the bounds of the drag area.
fields.summary: Dragging issues in backlog will halt if I'm not constantly moving the mouse

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Software Server*. Using *JIRA Software Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSWCLOUD-11966].
  {panel}

Customer is attempting to modify date format of date pickers in accordance with documentation located on an Atlassian Documentation site tailored to [Customizing the Look and Feel|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Customizing+the+Look+and+Feel#CustomizingtheLookandFeel-Date/TimeFormats]. 

All Customer functions have been replicated in a test environment using Ubuntu Linux 14.04 VM, JIRA Server 6.3.15. Customer navigates to Administration > General Configuration > Advanced Settings. Next, the customer changes the default value of jira.date.picker.javascript.format and jira.date.picker.java.format (exhibit A).  Updates occur without incident.

Meanwhile, from the Agile menu, customer specifies a Kanban Board ("KanBoardAcme"). Under "Try the enhanced reports in JIRA Agile Lab", customer elects the "Enable" button (exhibit B). Scroll to the bottom of that page, and see the TimeScale area fail validation. Please see (exhibit C).

When the Advanced Setting sets these values, they are global, are they not? Therefore, the date-picker should use those settings to enforce its validation rules.
fields.summary: Enhanced Reports - Custom date fields within enhanced reports compel a user to use d/MMM/yy validation scheme

fields.description:
We have an active sprint that when we view the burn down chart shows 70+ hours remaining.  When I run a JQL against the spring for remainingEstimate >= 0m and export the results to Excel I see: 19380 (seconds) or 5.38 hours.

The issue appears to be caused by our workflow.  When a issue is moved from our QA step (Ready for Testing) to Resolved we have a Transition Post function that sets the remaining estimate to 0m.  The burndown chart doesn't seem to recognize that the remaining estimate is 0m.  

It seems like the burndown chart is trying to use work log entries to figure out remaining estimate instead of using the actual remaining estimate.  I'll be honest we don't always use the work log entry, we should but we have a different time tracking system so most people don't use it when the work doesn't span more than a day.
fields.summary: Burndown Chart Issue

fields.description:
h3. Steps to Replicate
* Drag an issue from a status to another status. 

h3. Expected Result
Page refreshes and updates are shown correctly with the issue being shown under the status it is dropped in.

h3. Result
Page refreshes but updates are not properly shown. The dragged issue is still shown in the initial status and not under the status it is dropped in. When clicking on the specific ticket; can be seen from the ticket summary panel that the ticket is successfully transitioned. 

h3. Note
When checking on the Network analyzer; error 404 can be seen.

{noformat}
https://<le random instance>.atlassian.net/rest/greenhopper/1.0/rapidviewconfig/editmodel?rapidViewId=undefined&_=1428653295908
{noformat}
fields.summary: JIRA Agile board doesn't refresh and display updates correctly.

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Software Server*. Using *JIRA Software Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSWCLOUD-11948].
  {panel}

When a rapid board is based off of a filter query that pulls in issues across multiple projects, the rapid board's appearance is just like rapid boards in JIRA Agile before version 6.6.70.  

This what a board looks like with a single project in the filter query (project = LayOut ORDER BY Rank ASC):
!Screen Shot 2015-04-09 at 6.08.25 PM.png|thumbnail!

Add another project to the filter query (project in (LayOut, SketchUp) ORDER BY Rank ASC) and the board changes to look like this:
!Screen Shot 2015-04-09 at 6.13.05 PM.png|thumbnail!

The expectation is that the board's format would remain that same as in the first screenshot.
fields.summary: Boards configured with filter queries that pull issues from multiple projects do not show the project-centric sidebar

fields.description:
h3. Summary
After a UserPicker Field has been populated within a JIRA Classic Board, attempting to edit the field does not work.

h3. Environment

JIRA 6.3.14
Chrome 41, Firefox 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a Custom User Picker Field for a project you wish to test the JIRA Agile Classic Board with.
# Edit the Classic Board Project Configuration from the Classic Board: *Tools* > *Configuration*
# Open the Card Style Tab, and add the User Picker Field
# Return to the Classic Board and set the value of the Custom User Field to a specified user and commit the change.
# Attempt to update this field.

h3. Expected Results
Whenever a user clicks on the User Picker Icon, the User Picker Pop-up should open.

h3. Actual Results
If the Custom User Picker Field is not "None", the User Picker Pop-up will fail to open.

h3. Workaround
Users can open the the relevant issue, and manually set the value.
fields.summary: Classic Board Custom User Field User Picker Browser Not opening

fields.description:
I was delighted to see GHS-9689 implemented, which gives us a nice overview of how much work an assignee faces in an upcoming sprint.
However, the big drawback of this (as has been before) is the lack of Subtasks being shown and/or counted towards a total.

To keep things organized, we'd really like to use Epics to organize our big chunks, split them into Stories of small and defined features (which should, or rather must be finished together to have a working feature) and create Subtasks within them (because they should also automatically end up in the same sprint all the time) that, for example, belong one to a UI developer and one to a backend developer in the end.
Only when both are done, the story can be considered done - pretty much as Epics work right now on a big scale.
But since Subtasks are not shown in the "workload by assignee" view, we're back to square one where we don't actually know how much work someone is facing until the sprint is actually started.
fields.summary: Backlog Specialist Workload does not include Subtasks

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
To track the relation between time spent and customer value (Story Points) delivered throughout a sprint, it would be useful to have a chart that would combine the time estimate burndown and the value burnup over time. Essentially, it would be the Burndown Chart for time estimates, with an additional line for completed Story Points.

Mockup: !chart.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Combine Time Spent and Value Burnup in a Single Chart

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
At the moment, logging work against an issue, changes in remaining estimates and removing issues from sprints are reflected in the Burndown Chart in the same way. Hovering over an issue provides more details on the specific change, however, in the overview the difference isn't visible. It would be handy if scope changes and completed work were shown with e.g. a different colour of the line in the chart.

*Use case:* in teams that use burndown charts to communicate status to stakeholders outside of the team, it would make it clear when the team was getting work done, and when it was interrupted and had issues removed from the sprint backlog. It would serve as an early signal when sprint backlogs are frequently subject to change.
fields.summary: Differentiate Between a Scope Change and Completed Work in the Burndown Chart

fields.description:
h3. Summary
When an issue is closed and the Version is added to the issue after the fact, we see that reporting don't add up. According to the documentation found [here|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/AGILE/Viewing+the+Release+Burndown]. The ability to add issues to a version after they've closed should be supported.

For example, the Release Burndown and the Version Report show Inconsistent data. Version Report will show the information we expect while the Release Burndown won't include issues added to the version after they've been closed.

h3. Workaround

Re-open the issue and close it back out and the release burndown will begin to show the issues in the reports.
fields.summary: Inconsistent Reports Due To Version Being Added After Issue Closed

fields.description:
Under the Agile DropDown Menu, the Recent Boards list becomes pretty useless with >9 frequently used boards. 

*To Reproduce*
My first meeting of the day does not show up in the recent list and I have to take the following steps. 

# Click Agile / more...
# Get taken to a screen with the same list that's in the dropdown. 
# Click "All Boards" on the left hand side
# The list on All Boards is paginated, so the page is no longer text searchable, so I have to type the name of the project in the Jira "Find a Board" Searchbox.

Because I attend >9 standups in a day, I repeat this before every meeting because each board will have cycled off the recent list by the time I need it again. I frequently have less than 30 seconds between meetings.


Solutions would be any of the following, in order of preference:

* Have a notion of "favorite boards" with ability to order
* Allow customizing count or membership on recent boards page.
* Make "more..." button show all boards instead of recent boards because clicking more shows you only the boards you just skipped past.
* Make All Boards Page show all boards instead of paginating so that you can use browser text search.
fields.summary: Agile Recent Boards works poorly for many boards in use

fields.description:
Can we have a report showing information like this : 

Epic 1 - original estimates - remaining estimate - total time spent
Epic 2 - original estimates - remaining estimate - total time spent
Epic 3 - original estimates - remaining estimate - total time spent
Epic 4 - original estimates - remaining estimate - total time spent

As a workaround, it can be achieved through a JQL something like this : 
issuekey in (CP-967, CP-1063, CP-1055, CP-968) AND issueFunction in aggregateExpression("Total Estimate for all Issues", "originalEstimate.sum()", "Remaining work", "remainingEstimate.sum()", "Total time spent", "timespent.sum()")
fields.summary: Report showing remaining time, time spent, original time from a list of epics
